questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GCT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise. Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur. Lower end femur is Mc site for: Giant cell tumor Osteosarcoma Osteomyelitis
  • ➤ Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • ➤ Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • ➤ Lower end femur is Mc site for: Giant cell tumor Osteosarcoma Osteomyelitis
  • ➤ Lower end femur is Mc site for:
  • ➤ Giant cell tumor Osteosarcoma Osteomyelitis
  • ➤ Giant cell tumor
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma
  • ➤ Osteomyelitis

questions.text: A female 29 years old is on a Combined OCP regimen for contraception. All of the following cancers may be seen in her except (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ovarian cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. OCPs are protective against benign breast diseases, benign & malignant ovarian diseases but have been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and cervical cancer . Thus, ovarian cancer is the correct answer, as it is the exception.
  • • protective against benign breast diseases, benign & malignant ovarian diseases
  • • increased risk of breast cancer and cervical cancer
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Breast cancer: Combined OCPs may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer.
  • • Option A. Breast cancer:
  • • Option B. Cervical cancer: There is evidence that long-term use of combined OCPs can increase the risk of cervical cancer.
  • • Option B. Cervical cancer:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills reduce the risk of ovarian cancer while potentially increasing the risk of breast and cervical cancers.

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.correct_answer: A. Lifestyle modification and weight loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.
  • • Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification:
  • • Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.
  • • Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E:
  • • Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.
  • • Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

questions.text: A diabetic elderly man presents with dyspnea and pedal edema. A chest X-ray (CXR) shows an enlarged heart with rales. Echo reveals a low ejection fraction (EF). Which of the following treatments will delay the progression of cardiac disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Empagliflozin, although primarily an anti-diabetic medication, has been shown to significantly benefit patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) by delaying the progression of the disease through its effects on diuresis, myocardial metabolism, and cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Component bar graph

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

questions.text: Monkeypox detection is best done by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Real-Time PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Real-Time PCR is the most effective and reliable method for detecting Monkeypox virus, a double-stranded DNA virus, due to its sensitivity and specificity

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A. Hirschsprung's disease : This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.
  • • A.
  • • Hirschsprung's disease
  • • B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV) : PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).
  • • B.
  • • Posterior urethral valve (PUV)
  • • C. Choledochal cyst : This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.
  • • C.
  • • Choledochal cyst
  • • D. Intussusception : This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.
  • • D.
  • • Intussusception

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia, arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were present over the body. Probable drug of abuse in above patient is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine abuse can be identified by symptoms of tachycardia, arrhythmias, and the presence of scratch marks due to tactile hallucinations (cocaine bugs).
  • ➤ “Cocaine is the drug of abuse”
  • ➤ “Cocaine is the drug of abuse”

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic was presented with complaints of confusion, tingling sensation. His history revealed polished rice is his main diet. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Beriberi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic alcoholism and a diet primarily consisting of polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in Beriberi, which can manifest as either dry (neurological symptoms) or wet (cardiac symptoms) Beriberi.

questions.text: A patient with Reinke’s edema will have which of the following symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Dysphonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reinke's edema primarily affects the vocal cords leading to characteristic symptoms related to voice changes where the patient may experience pain due to movement of swollen vocal cords. Heavy vocal cords require more effort by the vocal muscles to move them. Hence this extra effort of muscles causes pain and early vocal fatigue to the patient. Management involves addressing the underlying causes, surgical intervention, and supportive therapies like voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dog

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dogs are the definitive hosts for the adult form of Echinococcus, underscoring the importance of proper hygiene and preventive measures in areas where these animals are common to minimize the risk of transmission and subsequent human infection.

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: Which of the following listed minerals is NOT typically classified as a trace nutrient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcium is a macronutrient, needed in larger amounts. Selenium, iodine, and copper are trace nutrients, required in smaller quantities.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malaria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

questions.text: What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020) Bilateral Mammography PET Scan Biopsy of the breast mass USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia? (Fmge Jan 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Restriction of water intake and wait and watch

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Alpha blocker

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alpha blockers, particularly α1A blockers like tamsulosin and silodosin, are used for the initial management of irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia. These medications help alleviate symptoms by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow without significantly affecting blood pressure.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) STD clinic attendees

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • ➤ Female sex workers.
  • ➤ Hijra/Transgenders.
  • ➤ IV drug users
  • ➤ Truckers.
  • ➤ Homosexual Men
  • ➤ Migrants.

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023) 1. General somatic 2. General visceral 3. Special somatic 4. Special visceral
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded). After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).
  • ➤ Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).
  • ➤ Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 176
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 176

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle. Values and Interpretation: Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH)
  • • Values and Interpretation: Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Values and Interpretation:
  • • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
  • • Normal value:
  • • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
  • • Poor ovarian reserve:
  • • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve:
  • • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted. Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction. Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones. Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.
  • • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • • FSH levels:
  • • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • • Serum estradiol values:
  • • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • • Antral follicular count on ultrasound:
  • • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.
  • • Inhibin B:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.
  • • Option A. Luteal phase LH:
  • • Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.
  • • Option B. Post luteal phase LH:
  • • Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.
  • • Option C. FSH in the follicular phase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg435
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg435

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

questions.text: A child presented to PHC OPD with skin rash and depigmented hair. He gives a history of swollen/bleeding gums. X-ray picture is shown below. He is suffering from: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Copper deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Copper deficiency can mimic vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) in its clinical and radiological presentation, a condition often referred to as pseudoscurvy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. He had no fractures and no hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. Non-contrast CT was performed and was found to be normal. The likely diagnosis is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.
  • • C/F: High energy trauma (road traffic accident) + Low GCS score / comatose
  • • C/F:
  • • Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds
  • • IOC for DAI → MRI
  • • IOC for DAI
  • • Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: Patients with post-concussion syndrome have mild traumatic brain injury. It does not present with a severe clinical status as seen in this patient.
  • • Option B. Post-concussion syndrome:
  • • Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage: Extradural hemorrhage results secondary to trauma to head. The bleeding is usually arterial and blood collects between outer dura and inner table of the skull. It can very well be visualized on CT.
  • • Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Post-concussion syndrome: A cerebral herniation is a shift of cerebral tissue in an adjacent space. Intracranial brain herniation can be classified into 3 types - subfalcine, trans tentorial and tonsillar. A distinct clinical picture can be produced as a result of compression of neurovascular structures by the herniating part. CT is the imaging modality of choice because it can be done rapidly.
  • • Option D. Post-concussion syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of road traffic accidents where a patient presents with a significant neurological deficit and a normal initial CT scan, diffuse axonal injury should be considered. An MRI with specific sequences is required to confirm the diagnosis and understand the extent of injury.

questions.text: A child has features of meningitis with following CSF examination: protein=93, glucose=20, Lymphocytes + Diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the CSF findings associated with different types of meningitis. Understand that the CSF profile, including elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis, can be indicative of tubercular meningitis. Be aware of the various etiologies and clinical presentations of meningitis in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

questions.text: What TNM stage is appropriate for a woman with a breast lump and peau d'orange appearance affecting more than two-thirds of the breast?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) T4d

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peau d'orange affecting more than one-third of the breast skin is classified as T4d, indicating inflammatory breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not carry parasympathetic fibers? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trochlear

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Among the cranial nerves, only the oculomotor (CN III), facial (CN VII), glossopharyngeal (CN IX), and vagus (CN X) nerves carry parasympathetic fibers. These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity in the head, neck, and face area. The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is not involved in parasympathetic innervation.
  • • The parasympathetic ganglia associated with these cranial nerves are:
  • • The parasympathetic ganglia associated with these cranial nerves are:
  • • Oculomotor (CN III): Ciliary ganglion, related to the eye Facial (CN VII): Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia, causing secretion from nasal, palatine, and submandibular glands Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): Otic ganglion Vagus (CN X): Responsible for secretion from the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)
  • • Oculomotor (CN III): Ciliary ganglion, related to the eye
  • • Oculomotor (CN III):
  • • Facial (CN VII): Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia, causing secretion from nasal, palatine, and submandibular glands
  • • Facial (CN VII):
  • • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): Otic ganglion
  • • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX):
  • • Vagus (CN X): Responsible for secretion from the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)
  • • Vagus (CN X):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Facial: The facial nerve (CN VII) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia.
  • • Option B. Facial:
  • • Option C. Oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the ciliary ganglion.
  • • Option
  • • C. Oculomotor:
  • • Option D. Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the otic ganglion.
  • • Option
  • • D. Glossopharyngeal:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic fibers are CN III, CN VII, CN IX, and CN X (3, 7, 9, 10). These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity and secretion in the head, neck, and face area, as well as the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Superior mesenteric vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Superior Mesenteric Vein can be distinguished on a CT scan by its position to the right of the Superior Mesenteric Artery, and its relation to the uncinate process. Remembering "SMAL" (Superior Mesenteric Artery Left, Superior Mesenteric Vein Right) can aid in identification during diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-
  • ➤ Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-
  • ➤ Angioedema Cough Taste disturbances (Dysguesia) Orthostatic hypotension Hyperkalemia They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.
  • ➤ Angioedema
  • ➤ Cough
  • ➤ Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • ➤ Orthostatic hypotension
  • ➤ Hyperkalemia
  • ➤ They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 180-220

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Cysto-Urethroscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The insertion of a double J stent in the ureter is performed using a cysto-urethroscope, which allows for direct visualization of the bladder and ureteric orifices, enabling accurate stent placement.
